an4.68:1: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Rājagaha on Mount Vulture Peak soon after Devadatta had left.[n.76] The sutta, including the verse, is also at SN7:35, II 24, with an added homily on the danger of gain, honor, and praise. See too Vin II 87–88.There the Blessed One, with reference to Devadatta, addressed the bhikkhus: "Bhikkhus, Devadatta's gain, honor, and praise led to his own ruin and destruction.
an4.68:2: (1) Just as a plantain tree yields fruit to its own ruin and destruction, so Devadatta's gain, honor, and praise led to his own ruin and destruction.
an4.68:3: (2) Just as a bamboo yields fruit to its own ruin and destruction, so Devadatta's gain, honor, and praise led to his own ruin and destruction.
an4.68:4: (3) Just as a reed yields fruit to its own ruin and destruction, so Devadatta's gain, honor, and praise led to his own ruin and destruction.
an4.68:5: (4) Just as a mule becomes pregnant to its own ruin and destruction, so Devadatta's gain, honor, and praise led to his own ruin and destruction."
an4.68:6: As its own fruit destroys the plantain,as its fruit destroys the bamboo and reed,as its embryo destroys the mule,so does honor destroy the vile man.
